Description: CMCC rulebook generated directly from Airtable base.

schema.name: IsEverythingALanguageId
schema.description: Unique identifier for this argument step in the 'Is Everything a Language?' logical framework (e.g., neial-001)

schema.name: Name
schema.description: Human-readable code name for the argument step (e.g., NEIAL-001, NEIAL-016)

schema.name: ArgumentName
schema.description: Name of the logical argument this step belongs to: 'LanguageCanBeFormalized' or 'NotEverythingIsALanguage'

schema.name: ArgumentCategory
schema.description: Category classifying the argument step's role: Definition, Premise, Example, Observation, or Conclusion

schema.name: StepType
schema.description: The specific logical function of this step: Motivation, PredicateSet, Definition, Witness, Entailment, Counterexample, NonLanguageExample, FuzzyBoundary, Refinement, or Conclusion

schema.name: Statement
schema.description: The prose statement expressing this argument step in natural language

schema.name: Formalization
schema.description: Formal logical notation representing the statement using predicate logic symbols (∀, ∃, ∧, ¬, →, ⇒)

schema.name: RelatedCandidateName
schema.description: Display name of the LanguageCandidate this argument step references as evidence or example

schema.name: RelatedCandidateId
schema.description: Foreign key linking to LanguageCandidates.LanguageCandidateId for the referenced candidate

schema.name: EvidenceFromRulebook
schema.description: Predicate values from the related candidate that support this argument step (e.g., HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True)

schema.name: Notes
schema.description: Additional clarifications, caveats, or implementation notes for this argument step

data.Name: NEIAL-001
data.Statement: To avoid the slogan 'Everything is a language', treat 'language' as a typed construct defined by testable properties (syntax, parsing, serialized meaning, and descriptor-role).
data.Notes: This keeps 'can be interpreted' separate from 'is a language system'.

data.Name: NEIAL-004
data.Statement: There exists at least one clear witness that satisfies the operational definition: English.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True; Meaning_Is_Serialized=True; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=False; DistanceFromConcept=2; Category=Natural Language
data.Notes: If any predicate is false in your current dataset for this witness, adjust the candidate record or relax the definition.

data.Name: NEIAL-016
data.Statement: Given a formalizable definition of language, not everything is a language; some things are better treated as sign vehicles or semiotic processes, with running applications as a key fuzzy region that benefits from explicit modeling.
data.Notes: This is the repo's thesis in one line.

data.Name: NEIAL-007
data.Statement: If Language(x) is defined by necessary conditions, then any x that fails at least one condition is not a language.
data.Notes: This is the standard move: a definition implies exclusions.

data.Name: NEIAL-008
data.Statement: Counterexample: a chair can be interpreted as a sign (status, design, function), but it does not constitute a language system under the operational definition.
data.Notes: This separates semiotic availability (can signify) from linguistic structure (has syntax/parsing/serialized meaning).

data.Name: NEIAL-009
data.Statement: Non-language example: A Thunderstorm can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; Meaning_Is_Serialized=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical event
data.Notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

data.Name: NEIAL-002
data.Statement: Use the repo predicates: HasSyntax, RequiresParsing, Meaning_Is_Serialized, IsOntologyDescriptor (spelled IsOngologyDescriptor in the dataset), plus auxiliary checks like CanBeHeld and HasIdentity.
data.Formalization: Predicates: Syntax(x), Parse(x), SerializeMeaning(x), OntDesc(x), Tangible(x)
data.Notes: We preserve the dataset's field name even when misspelled to match the generated schema.

data.Name: NEIAL-006
data.Statement: Therefore, 'language' can be formalized as a computable classification boundary over explicit predicates.
data.Notes: This is the concession: language is formalizable (at least operationally).

data.Name: NEIAL-012
data.Statement: Fuzzy case: A Running App often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
data.Formalization: Borderline(A Running App): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(A Running App) under static-serialization criteria
data.Notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

data.Name: NEIAL-013
data.Statement: Fuzzy case: Running Calculator App often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
data.Formalization: Borderline(Running Calculator App): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(Running Calculator App) under static-serialization criteria
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; Meaning_Is_Serialized=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Running Software
data.Notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

data.Name: NEIAL-010
data.Statement: Non-language example: A Coffee Mug can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=False; Meaning_Is_Serialized=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=True; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical Object
data.Notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

data.Name: NEIAL-014
data.Statement: Fuzzy case: A Game of Fortnite often contains embedded languages (code, UI grammars), but as an executing/interactive process it behaves like a dynamic system rather than a static serialized language artifact.
data.Formalization: Borderline(A Game of Fortnite): may contain ∃y Language(y) but ¬Language(A Game of Fortnite) under static-serialization criteria
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=True; Meaning_Is_Serialized=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=False; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Running Software
data.Notes: This is where traditional semiotics' 'anything is a sign' doesn’t neatly distinguish: (1) language-as-system vs (2) meaning-making interactive processes.

data.Name: NEIAL-005
data.Statement: There exists at least one clear witness that satisfies the operational definition: Python.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=True; RequiresParsing=True; Meaning_Is_Serialized=True; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=False; HasIdentity=False; DistanceFromConcept=2; Category=Formal Language
data.Notes: If any predicate is false in your current dataset for this witness, adjust the candidate record or relax the definition.

data.Name: NEIAL-003
data.Statement: Operational definition: an item x counts as a Language if it has syntax, requires parsing, serializes meaning, and functions as an ontology/descriptor system.
data.Notes: This is a deliberately 'strong' definition: it matches formal languages and many natural language representations.

data.Name: NEIAL-015
data.Statement: Refinement: distinguish LanguageSystem (syntax/parsing/serialization descriptor) from SemioticProcess (interactive/dynamic meaning production) and from SignVehicle (object/phenomenon used as a sign).
data.Notes: This gives you a place to put running apps and games without forcing 'language' to swallow everything.

data.Name: NEIAL-011
data.Statement: Non-language example: The Mona Lisa can be meaningful, but meaning here is not generated by an explicit syntax+parsing+serialization descriptor system.
data.EvidenceFromRulebook: HasSyntax=False; RequiresParsing=False; Meaning_Is_Serialized=False; IsOngologyDescriptor=True; CanBeHeld=True; HasIdentity=True; DistanceFromConcept=1; Category=Physical Object
data.Notes: These are strong candidates for 'sign vehicles' rather than 'languages'.

LanguageCandidates.Description: Table: LanguageCandidates - Contains entities being evaluated against the operational definition of 'language' using testable predicates

schema.name: LanguageCandidateId
schema.description: Unique identifier for the language candidate in slug format (e.g., 'english', 'a-coffee-mug', 'running-calculator-app')

schema.name: Name
schema.description: Display name of the candidate being evaluated (e.g., 'English', 'A Coffee Mug', 'Python')

schema.name: FamilyFeudMismatch
schema.formula:
=IF(NOT({{TopFamilyFeudAnswer}} = {{ChosenLanguageCandidate}}),
  {{Name}} & " " & IF({{TopFamilyFeudAnswer}}, "Is", "Isn't") & " a Family Feud Language, but " & 
  IF({{ChosenLanguageCandidate}}, "Is", "Is Not") & " marked as a 'Language Candidate.'")
schema.description: Diagnostic message identifying discrepancies between the calculated 'Family Feud' answer and the manually chosen classification

schema.name: FamilyFuedQuestion
schema.description: The canonical survey-style question: 'Is [Name] a language?' used for intuition testing

schema.name: Category
schema.description: Classification category: Natural Language, Formal Language, Physical Object, Physical event, Running Software, or MISSING

schema.name: TopFamilyFeudAnswer
schema.description: Calculated boolean indicating if this candidate would be considered a language by common intuition (all language predicates true, all non-language predicates false)

schema.name: ChosenLanguageCandidate
schema.description: Manual override flag: true if this candidate should be classified as a language regardless of calculated predicates

schema.name: HasSyntax
schema.description: Core predicate: Does this candidate have formal syntactic rules governing valid expressions?

schema.name: HasIdentity
schema.description: Predicate: Does this candidate have a unique, persistent identity (a specific instance vs. a type/class)?

schema.name: CanBeHeld
schema.description: Predicate: Is this candidate a tangible physical object that can be physically held?

schema.name: HasGrammar
schema.description: Derived predicate: Equivalent to HasSyntax - indicates presence of grammatical structure

schema.name: RequiresParsing
schema.description: Core predicate: Does understanding this candidate require parsing/interpreting structured input?

schema.name: MeaningIsSerialized
schema.description: Core predicate: Is meaning encoded in a serialized, transmittable form rather than immediate experience?

schema.name: IsOngologyDescriptor
schema.description: Core predicate: Does this candidate function as an ontology/descriptor system for categorizing concepts? (Note: field name preserves original 'Ongology' spelling)

schema.name: DistanceFromConcept
schema.description: Semiotic distance: 1 = direct mirror/instantiation of a concept (sign vehicle), 2 = description/representation of a concept (language)

schema.name: RelationshipToConcept
schema.description: Human-readable relationship type derived from DistanceFromConcept: 'IsMirrorOf' (distance=1) or 'IsDescriptionOf' (distance=2)

schema.name: SortOrder
schema.description: Display ordering index for presenting candidates in a consistent sequence

_meta._CMCC_Summary: Airtable export with schema-first type mapping: Schemas, Data, Relationships (FK links), Lookups (INDEX/MATCH), Aggregations (SUMIFS/COUNTIFS/Rollups), and Calculated fields (formulas) in Excel dialect. Field types are determined from Airtable's schema metadata FIRST (no coercion), with intelligent fallback to formula/data analysis only when schema is unavailable.

_conversion_metadata.field_type_mapping: checkbox→boolean, number→number/integer, multipleRecordLinks→relationship, multipleLookupValues→lookup, rollup→aggregation, count→aggregation, formula→calculated

type_inference.priority: airtable_metadata (NO COERCION) → formula_analysis → reference_resolution → data_analysis (fallback only)
type_inference.airtable_type_mapping: checkbox→boolean, singleLineText→string, multilineText→string, number→number/integer, datetime→datetime, singleSelect→string, email→string, url→string, phoneNumber→string
type_inference.data_coercion_hierarchy: Only used as fallback when Airtable schema unavailable: datetime → number → integer → boolean → base64 → json → string
